title: How to Homebrew Malt Extract Beer

steps.headline: Wash your 16 to 20 quart cooking pot, spoon and measuring cup with soapy water.
steps.description: Rinse it well with hot tap water. Make sure you get all the soap off.

steps.headline: Bring about 2 gallons (7.6 L) of water to a boil.
Dump your can of Hopped Malt Extract into the boiling water, stirring so as to not allow the thick malt to stick to the bottom of the kettle.
Add up to six cups of sugar, stirring until the sugar is completely absorbed by the boiling water.
steps.description: Four cups of sugar would be typical. The more sugar, the more alcohol, but be careful with this choice.

steps.headline: Bring it back to a slow boil for about 15 minutes.
Fill your kitchen sink with cold water.
steps.description: You can even put ice in the water if you like. Set the kettle (called a wort) into the cold water and bring the temperature down to between 75 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit.

steps.headline: Pour the contents of the wort into the sterilized 6 gallon (22.7 L) bucket.
Add water (tap water is okay most of the time) until you've reached 5 or so gallons, keeping the temperature of the water between 75 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit.
If you are using dry yeast, you need to Activate it by adding the dry yeast packet to about a half a cup of 95 degree Fahrenheit water and letting the yeast sit for a five to ten minutes.
Add your yeast by simply pouring it into the 6 gallon (22.7 L) bucket, a.k.a.
steps.description: The Carboy. You can stir it in, but it's probably better to not stir too vigorously.

steps.headline: Add a little water to your air-lock to seal the two openings.
Place your air-locked sealed lid on the Carboy and wait for between 7 to 10 days for your beer to ferment.
steps.description: Room temperature should be between 70 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit during the fermentation phase.

steps.headline: Wait.
steps.description: Your beer will be done fermenting when percolation has ceased for at least 12 hours. This is not an exact science. It can be bottled after 6 or 7-days, but some people wait up to two weeks. 7-days is a fairly safe bet.

steps.headline: Fill a small pot with a few cups of water and bring to a boil.
steps.description: Turn off the heat source and put all of your bottling caps in the pot. This will sanitize them.

steps.headline: Wash with soapy water, then rinse with hot water and then sanitize the 3/8th's inch tubing, any attachments like the funnel, measuring spoon, the filler tube, spouts and all bottles you plan on using by mixing a 1-tablespoon bleach / 1 gallon (3.8 L) water solution.
steps.description: Rinse with hot water to get any bleach solution off the equipment and bottles. It cannot be stressed strongly enough, the importance of never allowing anything that has not been sanitized to touch your brew after the boil.

steps.headline: Arrange your empty plastic bottles in something that will keep them standing straight up (not able to fall over) and using the small funnel, put 1/2 teaspoon of corn sugar into each bottle.
steps.description: This is called priming sugar and is the catalyst in the carbonation of your beer.

steps.headline: Remove the Carboy lid and gently stick the ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) plastic tube into the Carboy about an inch or two from the bottom.
steps.description: If you have a filler tube setup, you can probably touch the bottom of the Carboy as they are designed to do so. Otherwise, do not allow your tube to touch the bottom of the Carboy. Also noteworthy, if you have a petcock on your Carboy, you can most likely just attach the 3/8ths inch siphon tube to the petcock.

steps.headline: Have your empty bottles close and siphon/drain your beer into your empty bottles.
Place the caps on your bottles and wait at least two weeks before refrigerating and subsequently, drinking.
steps.description: Store in a room where temperatures are between 65 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit during the carbonation phase.

Add up to six cups of sugar, stirring until the sugar is completely absorbed by the boiling water. Four cups of sugar would be typical. The more sugar, the more alcohol, but be careful with this choice. Bring it back to a slow boil for about 15 minutes.  Fill your kitchen sink with cold water. You can even put ice in the water if you like. Set the kettle (called a wort) into the cold water and bring the temperature down to between 75 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit. Pour the contents of the wort into the sterilized 6 gallon (22.7 L) bucket.  Add water (tap water is okay most of the time) until you've reached 5 or so gallons, keeping the temperature of the water between 75 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit.  If you are using dry yeast, you need to Activate it by adding the dry yeast packet to about a half a cup of 95 degree Fahrenheit water and letting the yeast sit for a five to ten minutes.  Add your yeast by simply pouring it into the 6 gallon (22.7 L) bucket, a.k.a. The Carboy. You can stir it in, but it's probably better to not stir too vigorously. Add a little water to your air-lock to seal the two openings.  Place your air-locked sealed lid on the Carboy and wait for between 7 to 10 days for your beer to ferment. Room temperature should be between 70 and 80 degrees Fahrenheit during the fermentation phase. Wait. Your beer will be done fermenting when percolation has ceased for at least 12 hours. This is not an exact science. It can be bottled after 6 or 7-days, but some people wait up to two weeks. 7-days is a fairly safe bet. Fill a small pot with a few cups of water and bring to a boil. Turn off the heat source and put all of your bottling caps in the pot. This will sanitize them. Rinse with hot water to get any bleach solution off the equipment and bottles. It cannot be stressed strongly enough, the importance of never allowing anything that has not been sanitized to touch your brew after the boil. Arrange your empty plastic bottles in something that will keep them standing straight up (not able to fall over) and using the small funnel, put 1/2 teaspoon of corn sugar into each bottle. This is called priming sugar and is the catalyst in the carbonation of your beer. Remove the Carboy lid and gently stick the ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) plastic tube into the Carboy about an inch or two from the bottom. If you have a filler tube setup, you can probably touch the bottom of the Carboy as they are designed to do so. Otherwise, do not allow your tube to touch the bottom of the Carboy. Also noteworthy, if you have a petcock on your Carboy, you can most likely just attach the 3/8ths inch siphon tube to the petcock. Have your empty bottles close and siphon/drain your beer into your empty bottles.  Place the caps on your bottles and wait at least two weeks before refrigerating and subsequently, drinking.
